snippet: Only players with the most severe brain injuries will be compensated, and the estates of retirees who died before 2006 would be excluded, according to a draft of the proposed settlement.
abstract: National Football League's $765 million settlement with 4,500 retired players who said league hid from them the long-term impact of concussions may provide payouts to far fewer former players than originally thought; confidential letter outlining components of proposed settlement indicate that only those with the most severe brain injuries would be compensated, and estates of retirees who died before 2006 would be excluded.
lead_paragraph: Only players with the most severe brain injuries will be compensated, and the estates of retirees who died before 2006 would be excluded, according to a draft of the proposed settlement.

headline.main: Many Ex-Players May Be Ineligible for Payment in N.F.L. Concussion Settlement
headline.print_headline: Many Ex-Players May Be Ineligible to Share in N.F.L. Concussion Deal
